'Cell culture' is the complex process by which cells are grown under controlled
conditions, generally outside of their natural environment. In practice, the
term "cell culture" now refers to the culturing of cells derived from multi-
cellular eukaryotes, especially animal cells. However, there are also cultures
of plants, fungi and microbes, including viruses, bacteria and protists. The
historical development and methods of cell culture are closely interrelated to
those of tissue culture and organ culture.

Animal cell culture became a common laboratory technique in the mid-
1900s, but the concept of maintaining live cell lines separated from
their original tissue source was discovered in the 19th century.
